channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Harris vies for GOP votes while Trump courts Latinos in the race for the White House
item.description: Vice President Harris worked to woo Republican voters yesterday with an interview on Fox News and a speech in Pennsylvania. Meanwhile, Trump worked to gain the Latino vote at a Univision town hall.
item.content:encoded:
Vice President Harris worked to woo Republican voters yesterday with an interview on Fox News and a speech in Pennsylvania. Meanwhile, Trump worked to gain the Latino vote at a Univision town hall.

(Image credit: Ryan Collerd)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: 'End of an era': Biden heads for a farewell trip to Germany. Here's what to know
item.description: It's expected to be a meeting of great political importance — especially for Europe.
item.content:encoded:
It's expected to be a meeting of great political importance — especially for Europe.

(Image credit: Martin Meissner)
item.dc:creator: Esme Nicholson

item.title: From rodeos to radio, inside the Arizona fight against misinformation
item.description: Radio Campesina has a big goal this year: combat misinformation about elections among Arizona Latinos.
item.content:encoded:
Radio Campesina has a big goal this year: combat misinformation about elections among Arizona Latinos.

(Image credit: Caitlin O'Hara for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Ximena Bustillo

item.title: How to avoid sharing election misinformation
item.description: The 2024 election season is here. As we’re waiting to learn the final results, it can be easy to be duped by false or misleading information. Here are four tips to help you avoid spreading election related misinformation.
item.content:encoded:
The 2024 election season is here. As we’re waiting to learn the final results, it can be easy to be duped by false or misleading information. Here are four tips to help you avoid spreading election related misinformation.

(Image credit: DigitalVision Vectors)
item.dc:creator: Audrey Nguyen

item.title: ‘Horrifying’ mistake to take organs from a living person averted, witnesses say
item.description: At a hospital in Kentucky, witnesses say, a man who had been declared dead after a drug overdose was moving and visibly crying as he was prepped for surgery to donate his vital organs. The surgery was stopped and the man is alive three years later.
item.content:encoded:
At a hospital in Kentucky, witnesses say, a man who had been declared dead after a drug overdose was moving and visibly crying as he was prepped for surgery to donate his vital organs. The surgery was stopped and the man is alive three years later.

(Image credit: Hoover Rhorer Family)
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: Trump tried a friendlier pitch with Latino voters at a Univision town hall
item.description: During a town hall outside Miami, Trump touted his record on the economy, yet called Jan. 6 a "day of love" and would not back off false claims about Haitian migrants eating pets in Springfield, Ohio.
item.content:encoded:
During a town hall outside Miami, Trump touted his record on the economy, yet called Jan. 6 a "day of love" and would not back off false claims about Haitian migrants eating pets in Springfield, Ohio.

(Image credit: Chandan Khanna)
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: Archdiocese of Los Angeles agrees to pay $880 million to settle sexual abuse claims
item.description: The Archdiocese of Los Angeles has agreed to pay $880 million to victims of clergy sexual abuse in what an attorney said was the largest single child sex abuse settlement with a Catholic archdiocese.
item.content:encoded:
The Archdiocese of Los Angeles has agreed to pay $880 million to victims of clergy sexual abuse in what an attorney said was the largest single child sex abuse settlement with a Catholic archdiocese.

(Image credit: Damian Dovarganes)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: JD Vance says 'no,' he does not think Trump lost in 2020
item.description: Vance has faced repeated questions on the campaign trail about whether Trump lost in 2020. On Wednesday, he gave his most direct answer to date, answering "no" in response to a reporter's question.
item.content:encoded:
Vance has faced repeated questions on the campaign trail about whether Trump lost in 2020. On Wednesday, he gave his most direct answer to date, answering "no" in response to a reporter's question.

(Image credit: Matt Rourke)
item.dc:creator: Jason Breslow

item.title: New records show Texas judge on X case didn't sell his Tesla shares after taking the suit
item.description: The judge, Reed O’Connor, in Fort Worth, Texas, has rejected calls for him to step down from the high-profile case Musk filed against Media Matters, a watchdog group.
item.content:encoded:
The judge, Reed O’Connor, in Fort Worth, Texas, has rejected calls for him to step down from the high-profile case Musk filed against Media Matters, a watchdog group.

(Image credit: Julia Nikhinson)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: Harris interview on Fox gets testy — but also gives her a do-over
item.description: The interview was the vice president's first formal sit-down with Fox. She faced questions on immigration, and was given a chance to answer again what she would do differently from President Biden.
item.content:encoded:
The interview was the vice president's first formal sit-down with Fox. She faced questions on immigration, and was given a chance to answer again what she would do differently from President Biden.

(Image credit: Ryan Collerd)
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith
